page.title: 01Introduction to Thurlow
page.content: Our block covers the gently rolling countryside so typical of Suffolk with the River Stour and several small tributaries cutting the land from over 350 ft at the western end of the block to a valley of under 250ft at its eastern end, along which the river flows south. The aspect is mainly a patchwork of fields undercultivated with original hedgerows and small wooded areas. This pleasant landscape is part of a large estate farmed as economically and efficiently as any land in Europe. A few farmhouses and isolated cottages dot the countryside with the one small hamlet of Carlton Green but most of the habitation is concentrated in the adjoining villages of Great and Little Thurlow, with most houses sited in the long main street, their style showing a charming mixture of English cottage architecture.
